body:
OK, I won't notify you again about this release, but will get in touch when a new version is available. If you'd rather skip all updates until the next major or minor version, let me know by commenting `@dependabot ignore this major version` or `@dependabot ignore this minor version`. You can also ignore all major, minor, or patch releases for a dependency by adding an [`ignore` condition](https://docs.github.com/en/code-security/supply-chain-security/configuration-options-for-dependency-updates#ignore) with the desired `update_types` to your config file.

If you change your mind, just re-open this PR and I'll resolve any conflicts on it.

"Gremlin Server and drivers should replace the network layer with Arrow Flight" --> What factors make it infeasible to support WebSocket and Arrow Flight in parallel?

> "Gremlin Server and drivers should replace the network layer with Arrow Flight" --> What factors make it infeasible to support WebSocket and Arrow Flight in parallel?

My goal is to simplify development and support. WebSocket and Arrow Flight in parallel is a complication

> 

You don't think it would be safer to leave the WebSocket solution intact until the Arrow Flight solution has proven itself end-to-end? Stage 1, in this proposal, already involves replacing the transport layer.

> > 
> 
> You don't think it would be safer to leave the WebSocket solution intact until the Arrow Flight solution has proven itself end-to-end? Stage 1, in this proposal, already involves replacing the transport layer.

I think it's not difficult to use another endpoint for Arrow Flight and keep existing WebSocket solution for a transitional period

> I think it's not difficult to use another endpoint for Arrow Flight and keep existing WebSocket solution for a transitional period

I suggest updating the proposal to reflect that.
Stage 0: clone the end-to-end WebSocket solution and begin migrating it to Arrow Flight, keeping the original solution intact
Stage n: assess the WebSocket solution and retire it if no longer needed

Even at Stage n, caution will be necessary. I believe there are plenty of "dark" Gremlin clients which aren't part of the official code base or known Gremlin variants, and talk directly to Gremlin Server using WebSocket.

Thanks for submitting this proposal for discussion. I see this targets version 4.x. Maybe it's ok to take the big break there from websockets. If this proposal were targeting 3.x, we'd have to keep websocket communication for sure. 

If the proposal sticks to targeting 4.x then it seems like one of the big questions affecting the staging of an implementation would be a schema proposal for 4.x. I assume having that proposal would help you understand how to use the standard flight serialization and thus skip past using the current serializers as part of this implementation.

Ah, I didn't realize this was targeted at 4.x only. Disregard my "hot swap" concerns, then. For schema, I would like to take a common specification of a TinkerPop model like [this](https://github.com/CategoricalData/hydra/blob/main/hydra-haskell/src/main/haskell/Hydra/Impl/Haskell/Sources/Ext/Tinkerpop/V3.hs) or [this](https://github.com/CategoricalData/hydra/blob/main/hydra-haskell/src/main/haskell/Hydra/Impl/Haskell/Sources/Ext/Tinkerpop/Typed.hs) and transform it into concrete APIs like [this](https://categoricaldata.github.io/hydra/hydra-java/javadoc/hydra/ext/tinkerpop/v3/package-summary.html) in a number of languages (Java, Scala, Haskell right now; working on Python support, and there will be others). We should take a fresh look at requirements for the schema language.

i'm not sure that this is the right change. we are on jcabi-manifests:1.2.1 which depends on jcabi-log:0.14. Version 0.14 does not have mockito-core as a dependency:

https://github.com/jcabi/jcabi-log/blob/jcabi-0.14/pom.xml

It appears that mockito-core was added much later:

https://github.com/jcabi/jcabi-log/commit/fc86070ad065a7a5253f43b1bea5dac3f18af3ee

I think the proper fix is to either:

1. pin your version of jcabi-log to the one TinkerPop uses or at least a version prior to the change above
2. submit a PR to jcabi-log to make mockito-core a "test" `<scope>`  as I assume that is mistake that it is "compile" `<scope>`

This PR as is is incomplete fix and just an example on how it works for me and how I suspect issue could be resolved.

This PR also does not handle other 'int' based types only long and bigint. 

It is possible that there are also other than 'int' based unhandled cases in the deserialization.

Also at least float seemed to be transmitted as 0x07 (Double at https://github.com/apache/tinkerpop/blob/master/gremlin-core/src/main/java/org/apache/tinkerpop/gremlin/structure/io/binary/DataType.java) back from the server so additionally maybe something is off with python serialization of 'float' type.

Can aim to make a more proper PR if desired. Mostly I think tests to check that this won't break again would be needed.

I came here to support this change. There is a bug currently when attempting to build gremlin within a docker image.

**Describe the bug**
Using docker, when installing latest gremlin, downstream dependency `aiohttp` when building wheel due to bug in earlier version: https://github.com/aio-libs/aiohttp/issues/6600

**To Reproduce**
Create docker image with:
```
FROM python:3

RUN pip install gremlinpython
```
It's also seen with:
```
FROM python:3

RUN pip install aiohttp==3.8.1
```

**Expected behavior**
Wheel builds successfully

In introducing the new `gremlin-util` module there should be some Upgrade Documentation to accompany this change. It should probably make note why this change isn't a breaking one and what impact it might have during upgrade. 

Speaking of which, I can't think of a scenario where users should notice anything different in their upgrades unless they aren't using maven or something similar. If they were somehow manually managing jar files they might miss that `gremlin-util` was a new module i guess. I'd sorta advocated a hope for being able to test drivers along 3.5.x and 3.6.x so perhaps that swayed you in this direction. seeing it here gives me a bit of pause that we're going to somehow annoy folks by moving these classes about. 

how do you feel about taking this a step more slowly? the work you've done here shows that the change could be made without breaking too much. if we really wanted to test 3.5.x/3.6.x we could in the future always backport this commit to these branches. so, you could just target master now with this commit as it is. introduce a follow-on commit that renames packages if you like as we can take a breaking change in 3.7.x. you do have the issue of groovy in gremlin-util but making a note of that in commit comment will remind us of that issue if we decided to backport the commit.

If they were somehow manually managing jar files they might miss that `gremlin-util` was a new module i guess. I'd sorta advocated a hope for being able to test drivers along 3.5.x and 3.6.x so perhaps that swayed you in this direction. seeing it here gives me a bit of pause that we're going to somehow annoy folks by moving these classes about.

This seems reasonable to me. At the moment it seems like bringing these changes into 3.5.x/3.6.x is more of a nice to have and not a pressing need. It is probably best to avoid any potential issues until a need arises (such as a large increase in connection related issues with some of the GLV's).
